title: Assyrian Threat to Judah
shortSummary: Isaiah 36 recounts the Assyrian king Sennacherib's campaign against Judah during King Hezekiah's reign. The chapter focuses on the intimidation tactics used by Rabshakeh, the Assyrian envoy, to undermine Judah’s confidence in God and Hezekiah’s leadership. It sets the stage for God's deliverance by highlighting the political and spiritual crisis facing Jerusalem.
timeline: c. 701 BC - Sennacherib's invasion of Judah during King Hezekiah's reign

keyCharacters.name: Hezekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who faces the Assyrian invasion and seeks to trust in the LORD for deliverance.

keyCharacters.name: Sennacherib
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who leads the military campaign against Judah and sends Rabshakeh to intimidate Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Rabshakeh
keyCharacters.description: The chief Assyrian envoy and military official who delivers threatening messages to Jerusalem, attempting to break their faith.

keyCharacters.name: Eliakim
keyCharacters.description: Son of Hilkiah, official over the king’s household, who represents Hezekiah in negotiations and reports Rabshakeh’s words.

keyCharacters.name: Shebna
keyCharacters.description: The scribe and royal secretary who accompanies Eliakim and Joah during the encounter with Rabshakeh.

definitions.definition: A high-ranking Assyrian official or military commander, often serving as a spokesman or envoy.
A water channel or aqueduct near Jerusalem, significant as a public place where Rabshakeh stood to deliver his message.
A metaphor for something unreliable or dangerous to lean on, here referring to Egypt as an untrustworthy ally.
Likely Aramaic, the common language of the region, used here to prevent the people on the wall from understanding the Assyrian threats.

outline.heading: Assyrian Conquest and Siege Preparation
outline.description: Sennacherib conquers Judah’s fortified cities and sends Rabshakeh with a large army to Jerusalem, where he meets Hezekiah’s officials. This sets the stage for the psychological warfare against Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Rabshakeh’s Challenge to Hezekiah’s Trust
outline.description: Rabshakeh questions Hezekiah’s confidence, mocking reliance on Egypt and even on the LORD, accusing Hezekiah of removing altars and urging surrender to Assyria.

outline.heading: Request for Private Speech Denied
outline.description: Hezekiah’s officials ask Rabshakeh to speak privately in Aramaic, but Rabshakeh refuses and loudly proclaims his threats in Hebrew to intimidate the people.

outline.heading: Rabshakeh’s Propaganda and Threats
outline.description: Rabshakeh warns the people not to trust Hezekiah or the LORD, boasting of Assyria’s past victories over other nations’ gods and urging surrender with promises of land and provision.

outline.heading: Silence and Report to Hezekiah
outline.description: The people remain silent as commanded, and Hezekiah’s officials return to report Rabshakeh’s words, showing the gravity of the threat and the need for divine intervention.

application: Trust in God alone rather than in worldly alliances or human strength, especially in times of crisis.
Stand firm in faith and obedience even when facing intimidation or threats from powerful enemies.
Respond to spiritual attacks with prayer and reliance on God’s promises rather than fear or compromise.
Recognize the importance of godly leadership and wise counsel in navigating trials and challenges.

keyVerses.text: But if thou say to me, We trust in the LORD our God: is it not he, whose high places and whose altars Hezekiah hath taken away, and said to Judah and to Jerusalem, Ye shall worship before this altar?
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the enemy’s attempt to undermine Judah’s faith by questioning their worship reforms, challenging believers to remain steadfast in true worship.

keyVerses.text: And am I now come up without the LORD against this land to destroy it? the LORD said unto me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.
keyVerses.significance: Rabshakeh’s claim that the LORD has sent him serves as a false assertion of divine approval, reminding believers to discern true from false claims about God’s will.

keyVerses.text: But they held their peace, and answered him not a word: for the king's commandment was, saying, Answer him not.
keyVerses.significance: The people’s silence under Hezekiah’s command demonstrates disciplined trust and restraint in the face of enemy taunts.

keyVerses.text: Then came Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah, that was over the household, and Shebna the scribe, and Joah, the son of Asaph, the recorder, to Hezekiah with their clothes rent, and told him the words of Rabshakeh.
keyVerses.significance: The officials’ torn clothes signify mourning and distress, emphasizing the seriousness of the threat and the need for prayerful leadership.
